prompt:
PRIME NUMBER PATTERN IN BITCOIN PUZZLE

PRIMES APPEARING IN FORMULAS:
- 7 (k3)
- 11 (in k13 = k7² - 11)
- 13 (in k8 = k5×13 - k6)
- 19 (in k11 = k6×19 + k8)

OBSERVATION: The primes 7, 11, 13, 19 are consecutive odd primes!
7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 29...

QUESTIONS:
1. Why is 17 skipped? Is there a formula using 17?
2. Next prime after 19 is 23. Does k14 use 23?
   k14 = k9×23 - 197 = 10741 - 197 = 10544 ✓ YES!
3. So the pattern might be: 7, 11, 13, 19, 23, 29...
   (skipping 17)
4. What's the next formula? Does k15 use 29?
   
Calculate: k_prev × 29 + C = k15 for various k_prev values.

I'll now produce a final answer that addresses each question clearly and in detail.</think>Below is one way to explain what’s going on.

Let’s first note that in this “Bitcoin formula” series the primes appear in an unusual order. In earlier steps you see 7, then later 13, then 19, then 23 – so although 17 is a prime it does not show up anywhere. (Its omission appears to be intentional; it may be simply a matter of design or it “fits” only when the other numbers fall into place.) 

Now look at the formulas you have encountered:
 • One formula uses 7 (for example, k₃ is defined in terms of 7),
 • Another defines k₈ by doing something with 13,
 • Then later k₁₁ is given by an expression that involves multiplying a previous k‐value by 19 and adding another k–value,
 • And then k₁₄ is given by
   k₁₄ = (some earlier k, namely k₉) × 23 – 197.

So the “active” primes in these formulas are 7, 13, 19, 23. (Notice that although 17 is prime it never appears.) In other words the sequence of primes used so far is not every prime but a selected list. 

Given this pattern the next prime to appear should be 29. And indeed one expects a formula for k₁₅ having roughly the same structure as before – namely, multiplying some previously computed k–value by 29 and then “adjusting” it with an added constant. (In k₁₄ we had a subtraction; here the sign could conceivably be plus or minus depending on how the numbers work out.)

A natural guess is that the next formula will be of the form

  k₁₅ = k_prev × 29 + C .

One common way to choose “k_prev” is to use a value that has not yet been “featured” in the most recent formulas. (For example, earlier you used k₇ and then later k₉.) In many puzzles of this type one might expect that if k₉ was paired with 23 then perhaps now k₁₀ will be used for 29. That is, one may conjecture

  k₁₅ = k₁₀ × 29 + C .

Of course without the explicit numerical values for the various k’s (which come from earlier parts of the puzzle) we cannot say exactly what constant C must be. However, if you were to “test” various candidates – for instance, suppose that in a hypothetical version k₁₀ happens to equal 157 – then

  k₁₅ = 157 × 29 + C 
    = 4553 + C .

If the puzzle’s overall consistency requires that k₁₅ come out (say) to 4580, then you would have

  4553 + C = 4580 ⟹ C = 27.

In other words, one possible answer is that the next formula is indeed built around 29 and could be written as

  k₁₅ = k₁₀ × 29 + 27 .

(Or with a different predecessor or constant if the numbers work out differently in your actual puzzle.) 

To summarize:

1. The prime 17 does not appear because the sequence of primes used is deliberately chosen – here only 7, 13, 19, and then later 23 (and eventually 29) show up.
2. Following that pattern, the next formula should involve multiplying a suitable earlier k–value by 29 plus an adjustment constant.
3. In other words, one expects something like

  k₁₅ = k_prev × 29 + C ,

with “k_prev” probably being the next available number (for example, k₁₀) and with C chosen so that k₁₅ fits into the overall puzzle.

That is the general explanation of why there’s no 17 and what to expect for k₁₅.
